column2: In this intermediate stage he wavers--neither drawn in harmony with nature by his instincts nor yet wisely putting himself into harmony by his own free-will.

column2: Haven't seen much of you this trip, said Hurstwood.

column2: Well, I've been busy, said Drouet.
column3: Well, I've been busy, said Drouet.

column2: They talked some few minutes on general topics.
column3: They talked some few minutes on general topics.

column2: Say, said Drouet, as if struck by a sudden idea, "I want you to come out some evening."
column3: Say, said Drouet, as if struck by a sudden idea, "I want you to come out some evening."

column2: Out where? inquired Hurstwood.
column3: Out where? inquired Hurstwood.

column2: Out to my house, of course, said Drouet, smiling.
column3: Out to my house, of course, said Drouet, smiling.

column2: Hurstwood looked up quizzically, the least suggestion of a smile hovering about his lips.
column3: Hurstwood looked up quizzically, the least suggestion of a smile hovering about his lips.

column2: He studied the face of Drouet in his wise way, and then with the demeanour of a gentleman, said: "Certainly; glad to."
column3: He studied the face of Drouet in his wise way, and then with the demeanour of a gentleman, said: "Certainly; glad to."

column2: We'll have a nice game of euchre.
column3: We'll have a nice game of euchre.

column2: May I bring a nice little bottle of Sec? asked Hurstwood.
column3: May I bring a nice little bottle of Sec? asked Hurstwood.

column2: Certainly, said Drouet.
column3: Certainly, said Drouet.

column2: I'll introduce you.
column3: I'll introduce you.

column2: CHAPTER IX
column3: CHAPTER nine

column2: CONVENTION'S OWN TINDER-BOX: THE EYE THAT IS GREEN
column3: CONVENTION'S OWN TINDER BOX: THE EYE THAT IS GREEN

column2: Hurstwood's residence on the North Side, near Lincoln Park, was a brick building of a very popular type then, a three-story affair with the first floor sunk a very little below the level of the street.
column3: Hurstwood's residence on the North Side, near Lincoln Park, was a brick building of a very popular type then, a three story affair with the first floor sunk a very little below the level of the street.

column2: It had a large bay window bulging out from the second floor, and was graced in front by a small grassy plot, twenty-five feet wide and ten feet deep. There was also a small rear yard, walled in by the fences of the neighbours and holding a stable where he kept his horse and trap.
column3: It had a large bay window bulging out from the second floor, and was graced in front by a small grassy plot, twenty five feet wide and ten feet deep. There was also a small rear yard, walled in by the fences of the neighbours and holding a stable where he kept his horse and trap.
